feed.title: Reilly Q. Curran
feed.subtitle: The online resume documenting the many development projects of Reilly Q. Curran from the past years of academic and professional development.

entry.title: Magenta
entry.content:
Take a look at our team website!

The magenta project is one which aims to use the tensorflow framework to utilise machine learning to make better music and art.

I was the manager running a team which sought to apply several upgrades to the existing project. We chose to take on tasks revolving around the Music side of the project, as well as a couple of house keeping fixes.

For example, I personally developped a write up which enabled users to understand the command which generates new music, as well as the commands that allow them to fully control their music generation and train their own models for music patterns.

Another example of some house keeping we did was adding a propper download script to the project, this download script works on Linux OSs and requires existing software already be present on the target machine, however the full download can be completed in around half an hour, rather than however long it could have taken to write and execute every command manually.

We also overlayed a GUI, designing a PHP and CSS web-document which would allow the user to interact with the software without neccessarily having to learn too much command line. This GUI was also critical to our other upgrades to the machine learning, and music generation algorithms themself.
entry.summary: Take a look at our team website!

entry.title: C Language to Haskell
entry.content:
This project was an assignment undertaken in my senior year of college, in it I set out to develop a parser for a C-like language

While this task would appear a tiny bit intimidating, Haskell is rather un-intuitive when one learns to code in C family languages, the actual task was able to be broken down into three components, the parsers, the executers, and the reader.

Take a look at some of the code:

The Parsers would take appart the language instructions and read them in ans individual commands of one of three types, then filter them even further with several more specific items within those types of instructions.

The program executers, the function marked as eval, takes that parsed input, and executes it.
entry.summary: This project was an assignment undertaken in my senior year of college, in it I set out to develop a parser for a C-like language

entry.title: Assembly to Haskell Parser
entry.content:
At the start of my Senior year I learned some Haskell skills by developing a segment of an Assembly parser.

The part I specifically developed (viewable below) has more to do with the actual cases of Assembly commands, it executes based on the read in command.

It handles load, add, jmp, blz, and ret commands, and when tested in the full context was capable of reading in a list of commands and executing them all in sequence (even shifting between different parts of the list).
entry.summary: At the start of my Senior year I learned some Haskell skills by developing a segment of an Assembly parser.

entry.title: Scaffold Script
entry.content:
Check it out here!

This was done largely as a joke for one of my assignments, I wrote a bash script which generates the linked website. You may note upon observation that the linked website is an instructional guide which lays out how to develop a website scaffold ending in the disclaimer that the user could also develop a bash script which handles that for them…like I did.

A funny thing to note is that I included a link to a random image inserter, Lorem Picsum if you’re curious, in the script, and thus the website it generates will have a random image every time the site is reloaded.

Feel free to download the script and see for yourself!

entry.title: Interning with IBM
entry.content:
Over the summer of 2018 I carried out an internship with the cryptography division, during which I developed demonstrations of crypto-adapter card functions to be published online. I developed these web demos using C and tested the programs by moving them to a remote server and using Linux command line tools on that server via Putty.

On one occaision I coordinated with one of my co-workers to incorperate code he had developed separately in order to fully complete one of the projects I had been working on, specifically to trigger a pause in the demonstration to show another part of the code. When the time came to submit the code I commited the code to IBM’s custom Git repository, and was added to IBM’s changelogs.
entry.summary: Over the summer of 2018 I carried out an internship with the cryptography division, during which I developed demonstrations of crypto-adapter card functions to be published online. I developed these web demos using C and tested the programs by moving them to a remote server and using Linux command line tools on that server via Putty.

entry.title: My first Professional Site!
entry.content:
I built this website at the end of my softmore year using Bootstraps, some custom text animation, and a Whole lot of expirementing with Html and CSS tags.
As is propper for website development the initial site creation and requisition was the easy part, precisely coloring individual styles is much harder.

Check out my CSS:

As you can see, the title banner is made up of several moving parts. However, each different color of them has it’s own CSS tag. Another thing worth mentioning is the Modals. I developed 6 Modals that would open their own mini windows on the screen for the user to inspect my different projects. Because I like to go the extra mile though, they were also able to view 4 of those modals as their own websites too!

entry.title: Esper Group
entry.content:
Check it out!

This is a model E-Commerce site developed to show off the “Esper Group”, an affordable tourism application based on get togethers I designed the graphics and took the pictures myself for this site demo. This was meant to simultaneously be our introduction to navigation bars and also checkout process.

I gave it a dark more professional theme, and designed the logo based on the Esperantist Jubilee symbol.

Take a look at the html for the navigation bar!

entry.title: Grid Slides
entry.content:
Check it out!

This project was completed as a sort of secondary option to the flexbox gallery (and even uses the same pictures and links), the difference being that it uses a grid layout rather than the flex box pattern.

take a look at the CSS!

This single class highlight tags the children with the grid layout, and also sets the rules of the grid (in this case that there are 3 collumns). While we’re referencing the flex project however, it is also worth noting that the organized boxes are achieved with one class tag here, where two were required with the flexbox gallery demo.

entry.title: Flex Boxes
entry.content:
Check it Out!

This web project was designed to demonstrate the flexbox CSS system for organizing Media Cards. I actually took all the pictures myself. Some are from the Raquette River in back of my old apartment, others are pictures I have taken while on vacation, or for one while I was working for an alternative energy company.

Check out the CSS!

This was actually the first project in which I made use of buttons in my html. They (mostly >:) ) didn’t do anything, but they were there!
